titleStmt.title: Documents de Maximilien (Ier) de Béthune, Duc de Sully.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains three handwritten documents.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten booklet with five poems in Latin by Melissus, and one handwritten letter by Wilhelm Crecelius, apparently to Gustav Könnecke in Marburg, who was possibly the owner of the Latin manuscript. The manuscript was bound into medieval parchment fragments from a Christian prayer book, Germany, 15th century. Thick brownish paper. 1 col., 9 - 24 lines written in brown ink, one hand. 1-2-lines red and blue, sometimes with green and red penwork, minor initials, red rubrics, red underlinings, decorated floral borders.

titleStmt.title: Bitt- und Werbeschrift des Friedrich Freiherr von der Trenck.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: See also file ARC. Ms. Var. 305 2 127

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten petitionary letter to major von Humbold in Magdeburg, asking for mercy. The text includes also a description of one of the cups he made in prison, written with his own blood. In addition there is a handwritten copy of the text (app. 1930). The text is of dubious authenticity.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Handwritten fragment of an essay, referring to the question whether to live in Paris or not, two pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contins three items: 1) One handwritten letter to Mr. Luckner, libraire allemand, two pages, 2) one copperplate print of his bust, 3) the handwritten manuscript of his "3me Ode républicaine au Peuple français", eight pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten note of ten lines, dealing with a certain Sabatier, who was condemned to death in Palermo.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter, written in St. Petersburg, to Ivan F. Kalaidovitch, referring to his situation. The file includes also a German translation of the letter.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten text from an album referring to Russia.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter, written in Paris, to the assemblyman Jolivet.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter to an unknown addressee, written in Bonn, referring to Mozart and to a portrait of the composer, two pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains a handwritten and signed manuscript of six pages, showing corrections and additions.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Handwritten essay 'Meinungen und Gedanken', referring also to Richard Wagner, Johann Sebastian Bach, Johannes Brahms, Hugo Wolf, and Franz Schubert.

titleStmt.title: Paul Armand Silvestre: Contes gais démocratie.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten manuscript of two pages, signed.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains two autographs: 1) A review on Georges Rodenbach's "Le voyae dans les yeux", signed A.S., one page 2) The handwritten poem "Tsilla", five pages.

titleStmt.title: Briefe an Ludwig Jacobowski, André Suarès, Kläre Dreifuss-Hirsch, Abraham Shalom Yahuda (?), Dora Mitzky und Claire Goll.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains letters from Zweig to: Ludwig Jacobowski: two photocopies of a handwritten letter, written in Vienna, referring to the collection of poems "Lieder für das Volk", 1900, André Suarès: photocopy of a typed letter transcript, written in Salzburg, referring to the death of Rilke, and to Tolstoi, 1927, Kläre Dreifuß-Hirsch: one handwritten letter to her and a typed transcript, 1932, Abraham Shalom Yahuda (?): two typed letters to him, referring to a new secretary and to a lecture, 1937-1938 Dora Mitzky: two letters, one handwritten, one typed, written in London and Bath, and one marriage announcement with a handwritten note. The letters refer to Joseph Roth and Arturo Toscanini, 1939-1940, Claire Goll: photocopies of four handwritten and typed letters, written in Bath and New York, referring to his book on Brazil and to Goll's works.

titleStmt.title: Charles W. Dilke: The Queen of England.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains a handwritten and signed manuscript of the essay, showing some additions and corrections, ten pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. I of VI

summary.ab: The file contains 32 letters and 25 postcards, all handwritten. One letter was written by André Beaunier ("Le Figaro"). They refer to Zweig's translations of Verhaeren's works, to meetings of both, to publications, and mention Camille Lemonnier, Theo van Rysselberghe, Willy Schlobach, Ellen Key, Léon Balzagette, Paul Verlaine, and Johannes Schlaf.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Handwritten address, one page.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains the handwritten draft of the novella "L'Escapade", with many corrections, signed by the author, pp. 1a-19a.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 35 handwritten letters, 17 postcards, two fragmented copies of letters, two notes and 4 newspaper clippings. One postcard shows a portrait of Lemonnier at the backside, 1912. In addition, there is the envelope in which Zweig sent the letters to Jerusalem. The letters refer to meetings between both, to publications, to Verhaeren and to Rathenau.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains five handwritten postcards, referring to meetings and to a book sent by Zweig.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of two handwritten postcards and one note, written in Berlin, referring to Zweig's publications.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 23 handwritten and typed letters, ten postcards, and three poems by Fleischer, written in Komotau, Leipzig and Vienna. The letters refer to private matters, to Victor Fleischer, Zweig's books, E.M. Lilien, Felix Braun, and to Fleischers edition of translated Chinese poems "Porzellanpavillion".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 24 handwritten letters, 32 postcards, one printed thank-you card, and one printed poem "Aufruhr" by Verhaeren, translated by Dehmel. Twelfe of the letters and postcards were sent by Ida Dehmel. The letters refer to translations of poems by Verlaine, to sent books, to performances of Dehmels plays, to Zweig's "Jeremias" and to differences between both concerning nationalism and consequences from the war.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 14 handwritten letters and 13 postcards, written in Vienna, Zehlendorf and Heppenheim, referring to their publications, to a review on Buber's "Daniel, Gespräche von der Verwirklichung", to articles by Zweig for "Der Jude", to Rolland, Max Brod, and S.J. Agnon.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One photo postcard, written in Vienna, with a handwritten note to an unknown addressee.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The originals are held by the Archives et Musée de la Litterature, Bruxelles

summary.ab: Copies of 38 handwritten letters, six postcards and one telegram, plus a copy of a contract with the Insel-Verlag.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 37 handwritten and typed letters, three postcards, and one note, written in Vienna, Zurich, Buffalo, and Washington. The letters refer to the newspaper "Die Zeit", to the P.E.N. club Austria, to publications of both, to the death of Zweig's mother, to Max Reinhardt, Lucy von Jacobi and her immigration, and to Emile Verhaeren.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten letter, written in Edlach, referring to a letter from Zweig.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter to a translator, referring to German and Czech translations of his works, written in Linalyst, two pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 19 letters, 24 postcards, three letter cards, all handwritten, one photograph of Ellen Key, 1904, and the envelope in which Zweig sent the letters to Jerusalem. The letters refer to Zweig's novellas, to Rilke, Verhaeren, Rodin, to the role of women in literature, to the Nobel price for literature and the candidacy of Verhaeren and Maeterlinck for it, and to Key's attitude to Germany during World War I.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains four handwritten and typed letters,written in Vienna, referring to the satiric journal "Der liebe Augustin".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: See also file ARC. Ms. Var. 305 1 136.

summary.ab: The file contains 24 letters, 78 postcards (all handwritten), two telegrams and one note. The letters deal with Bahr's reading tours, with the meaning of World War One for Europe, with meetings of both, and Bahr's illness, as well as with Walt Whitman, Emile Verhaeren, Lev Tolstoi, and Hugo von Hofmannsthal. Included is one handwriten copy of a letter from Bahr to Karl Graf Stürgkh, prime minister of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, asking for pardon for the Croatian poet Ivo Vojnović, 1916. On the backsides of three postcards (1927, 1929) there are portraits of Bahr.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains two letters and 29 postcards, all handwritten. On the back of one postcard a portrait of Harden. The postcards refer to Zweig's articles published by Harden and express thanks for sent books.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 28 handwritten and typed letters, and 23 postcards, written in Vienna, Voslau, Budapest and at the front during World War One, referring to Wolf's poems, novellas and novels, to Zweig's works, to meetings of both, and to the affair of Georg Kulka and Karl Kraus on plagiarism in "Die Fackel".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter to Helene Klepetar, written in Copenhagen.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 61 handwritten and typed letters, 38 postcards and one printed article "Zum ewigen Frieden". The letters were written in Prague and Tel Aviv, and refer to meetings of both, to performances of Brod's compositions in Prague, to the journal "Arkadia", to the "Neue Freie Presse", to the publication of Franz Kafka's "Das Schloss", to the written estate of Kafka, to the question of the settlement of all Jews in Palestine (according to Jabotinsky), to Jewish identity, and to Emile Verhaeren, Egon Erwin Kisch, Aenne Markgraf, Heinz Politzer, and Nathan and Uriel Birnbaum.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: File ARC. Ms. Var. 305 1 155 contains photocopies of the letters' transcripts.

summary.ab: The file contains 21 handwritten letters, referring to a lecture by Rilke in Vienna, to the question of Christian sacraments, to an autograph of Rilkes "Cornet", to the works of both, and to Ellen Key, Emile Verhaeren, Romain Rolland, Frederik van Eeden, and Sil Vara.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of five handwritten letters and 15 postcards, written in Berlin and Westerland, referring to publications of both.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 52 handwritten postcards and letter cards, 24 handwritten and typed letters, one telegram, and two copies of a declaration concerning newspaper articles published in Russia and in the USA during World War One. In addition, there are one letter and three cards by Olga Schnitzler, and the envelope, in which Zweig sent the letters to Jerusalem. The letters refer to meetings of both, to books sent to each other, to a reading by Schnitzler in Vienna, to the prohibited performance of "Prof. Bernhardi" (including a typed copy of the prohibition, 1913), to an auction with autographs by Schnitzler in Berlin (1929), to Ludo Hartmann, Romain Rolland, Richard Rosenbaum, Walther Rathenau, and Alzir Hella.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten postcard to Helene Klepetar, written in Turö, referring to an article by Klepetar in the 'Neue Freie Presse'.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. II of VI

summary.ab: The file contains 25 handwritten letters and 16 postcards, and the original envelope in which Zweig sent the materials to Jerusalem. The letters refer to theaters in Brussels and Paris, to publications (Hélène, Philipp II), to translations of Verhaeren's works into German, and to Ellen Key, Léon Balyagette, Maeterlinck, Rilke and Alfred Vallette.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten postcard to Helene Klepetar, written in Copenhagen, mentioning a meeting with Georg Brandes.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 7 handwritten and typed letters, and 3 postcards, referring to Zweig's play "Tersites" and performances of it.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten letter and one postcard, referring to Zweig's poems and Reger's intention to use them for his work as a composer.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of typed transcripts of the 21 letters in file ARC. Ms. Var. 305 1 56.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 29 handwritten and typed letters, three postcards, four telegrams and a print of his obituary on Emil Rathenau. Four letters were written by Rathenau's secretary, Hugo Geitner, and one by P. Kahn, the administrator of Rathenau's will. Also included is the envelope in which the letters were sent by Zweig. The letters are dealing with meetings between Zweig and Rathenau and their publications, with Romain Rolland, and with the political affair of Maximilian Harden. Others mention Cassirer, Gerhart Hauptmann, Albert Ballin, and Zweig's travel to India.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 50 handwritten and typed letters, and 10 postcards, of which three are written by Beatrice Zweig, one postcard from Paul Hoffmann (on Heinrich von Kleist) and one letter by Alice Balint. The letters were written in Arosa, Garmisch, Starnberg, Berlin, Haifa, and London, and refer to meetings of the two authors, to their works, to autographs, to the play "Der Streit um den Sergeanten Grischa" performed at the Volksbühne in Berlin, to the German culture in times of dictatorship, to Stefan Zweig's marriage with Lotte, to Arnold Zweig's accident in Palestine, and to Emile Verhaeren, Sigmund Freud, Max Eitingon.

titleStmt.title: Cartolina postale dell' Giovanni Placido Agostino Pascoli.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten postcard to Edoardo de Fonseca, written in Rome.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 35 handwritten and typed letters, including one letter by his daughter Christine, five postcards, one telegram from his son Raimund, and dedicated newspaper clippings with Hofmannsthal's article "Balzac", published in "Der Tag", 1908. In addition, there is the envelope in which Zweig sent the letters to Jerusalem. The letters refer to Zweig's literary contributions and publications, to Verhaeren, and to Hofmannsthal's "Österreichische Bibliothek".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 13 handwritten letters, 34 postcards and letter cards, one letter from W. Wassermann, one from Julie Wassermann, and one card from her. Also included is the envelope in which Zweig sent the materials to Jerusalem. The letters refer to the publications of both, to disputes between them and following interruptions in the correspondence (1912-1915, 1917-1928), to Emil Lucka, and to the request of Wassermann to get a loan from Zweig (1933).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains four handwritten letters, of which one is by Grete Kainz, all written in Vienna. The letters deal mainly with Zweig's play "Tersites".

titleStmt.title: Sigmund Freud, Anna Freud, Anna Bernays.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 20 handwritten and typed letters, six postcards and letter cards and one telegram. Six letters and one postcard were written by Anna Freud, one letter by Anna Bernays, Freud's oldest sister. The letters refer to Zweig's works, to Freud's contribution to the "Liber amicorum" to Romain Rolland, and to Zweig's study on Freud.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 24 handwritten and typed letters, 14 postcards, and one telegram. In addition, there is the envelope in which Zweig sent the materials to Jerusalem. One postcard shows a photograph of a bust of Wildgans, made by G. Ambrosi. The letters refer to Zweig's support of Wildgans with the editors of the journal "Jugend", to the "Bauernfeld-Preis" won by Wildgans, to publications of both, to the death of Zweig's father, and to Baudelaire, Verlaine, Kolbenheyer and Laurenz Wiedner.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 59 handwritten and typed letters, 79 postcards, one telegram and one note, written in Berlin, Wiesbaden and Vienna. The letters refer to Lissauer's and Zweigs' publications, to the Insel publishers, to the attitude of both on World War One, to the sitaution after 1933, to Paul Zech and Franz Werfel.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. III of VI

summary.ab: The file contains 26 handwritten letters and 18 postcards. Two letters were written by Marthe Verhaeren, one letter by Alfred Vallette and one by Baron von Gersdorff (secretary of Max Reinhardt), both to Verhaeren. In addition, there is the envelope in which Zweig sent the materials to Jerusalem. The letters refer to Max Reinhardt, to Maeterlinck, to the translations of Verhaeren's works, to Erna Rehwoldt, Hugo von Hofmannsthal, and Auguste Rodin.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of two handwritten notes, referring to appointments.

titleStmt.title: J.-H. Rosny aîné (Joseph Henri Honoré Boex).
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains the handwritten and signed manuscript of "La Cordouane", nine pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One visiting card with a handwritten note to Helene Klepetar, written in Copenhagen. The file includes also one envelope sent to Klepetar from Berlin in 1910.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. X of XIII

summary.ab: 126 envelopes of letters sent to Zweig

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. I of XIII

summary.ab: The file contains 33 handwritten letters, nine postcards, and two newspaper clippings, dealing with a meeting of Zweig and Rolland in Paris 1911, with the translataion of Rolland's "Jean Christophe", with several articles by both, with Rolland's work at the L'Agance internationale des prisionners de guerre a Genève, and with Oskar Fried, Emile Verhaeren, Stendhal, Thomas Mann, Arthur Schnitzler, and Rainer Maria Rilke.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Zweig's letters to Rolland, microfilm 4

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains four typed letters and one envelope used by Zweig for sending some of the letters to Jerusalem. The letters refer to Verhaeren and Zweig's works on him.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains two handwritten letters and one card, all written in Vienna, referring to publications of both.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. IV of VI

summary.ab: The file contains 13 handwritten letters and twelve postcards, one letter by Kleppik(?), and one letter written by Marthe and Emile Verhaeren. In addition, there is the envelope in which Zweig sent the materials to Jerusalem. The letters refer to the efforts of others to suggest Verhaeren as a candidate for the Nobel prize, to Anton Kippenberg, Johannes Schlaf, Maurice Maeterlinck, and Max Reinhardt.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains ten handwritten letters, one postcard by Gerda Busoni, one telegram from Heller concerning Busoni, and one envelope used by Zweig for sending the letters to Jerusalem. The letters refer to articles and plays by Zweig and Busoni's travels and concerts.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA). See also file ARC. Ms. Var. 305/1/22.

summary.ab: Photocopies of two handwritten letters and one postcard, referring to the publications of Bahr and Zweig.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter to a ladyfriend, one page, written in Zehlendorf, mentioning Julie Wassermann and Andreas Haukland.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten letter thanking for sending the book about Verhaeren.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 18 handwritten and typed letters, 11 postcards, and one telegram. The letters refer to a collection for the benefit of Franz Wedekind, to Rolland and his stay in Switzerland, to some autographs by Mann sent to Zweig, to the role of the pacifist activists after the end of World War I, to a reading tour of Mann to Salzburg, and to a collection for Goethe's birth house in Frankfurt a.M., signed by Mann and Max Reinhardt.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 38 handwritten and typed letters (one including the handwritten poem "Morgengebet"), 69 postcards, and one telegram, written in Berlin, Vienna, Leipzig, Dresden, Kilchberg, Zurich, Capri, Viganello, and Brissago. The letters refer to the "Neue Freie Presse", to book reviews, to the works of both authors, to the Rowohlt publishers, to the support for WIlhelm Schmidtbonn and for Oskar Kokoschka, and to Carl Ehrenstein, Leonhard Frank, Kurt Wolff, Karl Kraus, Alfred Adler, and Rahel Sanzara.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Handwritten and signed text comprising six aphorisms, written in Zehlendorf.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. V of VI

summary.ab: The file contains 15 handwritten letters and 16 postcards. Two letters were written by Marthe Verhaeren. In addition there is the envelope in which Zweig sent the materials to Jerusalem. The letters refer to a travel through Germany, to the translations of Verhaerens "Rembrandt" and "Rubens" by Zweig, to Max Reinhardt and Ellen Key.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains three handwritten letters, referring to Zweig's works, in particular to his novellas and to Verhaeren, as well as to the fate of Poland and its inhabitants in World War One.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter of three pages, written in Harpefoss.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. VI of VI

summary.ab: The file contains 15 handwritten letters and 18 postcards, and the envelope in which Zweig sent the materials to Jerusalem. One postcard is also signed by Anton Kippenberg and by Rainer Maria Rilke (1913), another one signed also by Oskar Fried (1914). The letters refer to Verhaeren's travel through Russia in 1913, and to Paul Zech, Anton Kippenberg, Romain Rolland, and Franz Dehmel.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten postcard, referring to publications.

summary.ab: Photocopies of 17 handwritten letters, nine postcards, six telegrams and one letter fragment, written in Vienna, Breitenstein and Capri. The letters refer to Zweig's works, his collection of autographs, to Verlaine and to Lia Rosen.

summary.ab: Photocopies of six handwritten and typed letters and five postcards, written in Neuilly sur Seine and Czernowitz, referring to Zweig's "Jeremias" and to meetings of both.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of seven handwritten letters, and two postcards, written in Vienna and Dresden, referring to his theater roles and to Willy Haas and Albert Ehrenstein.

summary.ab: Photocopies of two handwritten letters, written in Mittelschreiberhau, referring to publications.

summary.ab: Photocopies of 13 handwritten letters and one postcard, written in Genève, Berne, Zurich, Roveredo-Capriasca, and Rome, referring to composers, Bloch's compositions and to Romain Rolland.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten letter, one postcard, and one card, referring to a meeting of both and to Richard Friedenthal.

titleStmt.title: Paul Claudel: Idees sur la mise en scène de la "Verkündigung" pour Max Reinhardt.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains a handwritten concept for the scenery of Reinhardt's play, three pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. II of XIII

summary.ab: The file contains 40 handwritten letters, four postcards, newspaper clippings with articles by Rolland, and two handwritten poems, one by Frederik van Eeden, "An meine Freunde in Ost und West" (handwritten copy by Rolland), the other by Ethel Sidgwick "Credo". The letters deal with prisoners of war, with pacifist intellectuals, with published articles by Zweig and Rolland, and with Heinrich Mann, and Arthur Trebitsch.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains four handwritten letters, written in Munich and Rothenburg o.d. Tauber, referring to articles and manuscripts of Przybyszewski.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 75 handwritten and typed letters and 23 postcards, plus one typed letter from Zweig to Weiss, September 1937. The letters were written in Munich, Berlin, Prague, Paris, Vienna, and Neuilly. They refer to the publications of both, to reviews of Weiss' books by Zweig, to the situation in Europe, to Rahel Sanzara, Joseph Roth, and Thomas Mann.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains two letters and four postcards, all handwritten, referring to Zweigs review of Adolf Gelbers "1001 Nacht".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The letters were previously stored in the Schwadron autographs collection.

summary.ab: The file contains eight handwritten and typed letters, written in Vienna and Salzburg, referring to S.J. Agnon and Heinrich Brody concerning an anthology of Hebrew poetry.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten postcard, bearing also the signature of Andreas Ady.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten postcard, referring to the play "Sommer" by Sřamek, accepted by a theater in Vienna.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten letter thanking for the play "Jeremias".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of four handwritten and typed letters, one postcard and two notes, written in Vienna, referring to books of both and their translation.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Previously the file was kept among the correspondence of Zweig, Rolland file IX.

summary.ab: The file includes: 1. "Le Jeu de l'Amour et de la Mort", handwritten introduction with personal dedication to Zweig, seven pages, 30 August 1924; 2. "Jeremias de Stefan Zweig", handwritten manuscript for an article, which was published in "Die Friedenswarte" in 1918, six pages, including one letter from the editor Alfred Hermann Fried; 3. Liste de Membres du C.L.I., handwritten list including 67 names, some of them known writers 4. Short description of the contents of "Clerambault", handwritten, one page, 1917, and one typescript with handwritten corrections of six pages from the novel 5. notes on Clerambault, handwritten, four pages 6. notes about Pierre Hamp (Henri Bourrillon), handwritten, one page 7. "Au nom de Beethoven", handwritten manuscript, two pages, 19 December 1920 8. one handwritten telegram to Zweig, apparently never sent

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter, written in Berlin, asking to support his candidacy at the Stockholm academy (Nobel comittee?).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 16 handwritten and typed letters, and three postcards, written in Genève, Montreux, Berlin, Duesseldorf, and Vienna, and referring to theater performances, to Zweig's works, to the International Socialist Conference in February 1921 in Vienna, and to Romain Rolland, and Georg Friedrich Nicolai.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten postcard to Helene Klepetar, written in Berlin.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. III of XIII

summary.ab: The file contains 52 handwritten letters, five postcards, two notes and one telegram. The letters deal with Rolland's work "Jean Christophe", Zweig's play "Jeremias", with a meeting of both in Switzerland, with the end of World War I, and with Paul Seippel, Emile Verhaeren, Friderike von Winternitz, Annette Kolb, and Alfred Hermann Fried.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: See also ARC. Ms. Var. 305 1 153

summary.ab: The file contains five handwritten and typed letters, three postcards, and one telegram, referring to Mann's book "Der Untertan", to his travel to Austria in 1920, and to Zweigs plan to suggest Siegmund Freud as a candidate for the Nobel price.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 21 handwritten and typed letters, and one copy of a letter from Zweig, as well as two appeals against war and armament. The letters refer to the journals "Clarté", "L'Humanité", and "Monde", and to Zweig's contributions to them.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. XI of XIII

summary.ab: 213 envelopes of letters sent to Zweig

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The letter was previously stored in the Schwadron autographs collection.

summary.ab: One typed letter, written in Salzburg, referring to the performance of "Jeremias" and to a play by Romain Rolland.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains four handwritten and typed letters, and one letter draft from Zweig. The letters refer to a manifest on humanism and on Einstein's leaving from Germany.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopy of one handwritten letter, written in Munich, on real estate in Salzburg.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. IV of XIII

summary.ab: The file contains 55 handwritten letters, and nine postcards, among them two notes and one letter from Madeleine Rolland. The letters deal with pacifism, with letters from Beethoven, with Zweig's "Bibliotheca Mundi", and with Rolland's "Vie de Tolstoi". Some of the letters mention Adam Kuckhoff, Bertrand Russell, and Yvan Goll. The file includes also one print concerning the Nobel price for peace (Dispositions speciales regardant l'attribution du prix Nobel de la paix, two pages, 1905).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of two handwritten letters and one telegram, written in Munich, referreng to Agnon's contribution to an antology.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of three handwritten letters and one postcard, referring to Emma Goldman and to Magnus Hirschfeld (Mann's brother).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten letter, written in Kagel in der Mark, thanking for the book "Drei Meister" and reflecting on it.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 26 handwritten and typed letters and six postcards written in Salzburg and in Berlin. The letters concern Rosenkranz' place as a Jew in Germany, his first steps in literature, the J.M. Spaeth Verlag and publishing issues in general. In addition, there is a handwritten draft of a letter from Rosenkranz to Zweig concerning the volume of novellas "Verwirrung der Gefühle" (1926).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: See also file ARC. Ms. Var. 305 1 144

summary.ab: The file contains four handwritten letters, and one postcard, which refer mainly to Zweig's books on Dostoevski and Tolstoi.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopy of one handwritten postcard, written in Vienna, referring to a meeting.

titleStmt.title: Friderike Maria Zweig an Hans Rosenkranz.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains two handwritten postcards and two letters, written in Salzburg, concerning the publication of the German translation of Anatole France's book on Jeanne d'Arc, translated by Friderike Zweig and published by Rosenkranz in the J.M. Spaeth publishing house.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains two handwritten letters, one of them to Chapman and Hall, and one note. The refer to Zweig's works and to Romain Rolland.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 15 handwritten letters and three telegrams. Most of the letters in French and English have been translated by Gorky's secretary, but were signed by him, only two letters are in original Russian. One letter was written and signed by Gorky's partner, Moura Budberg. Included is also one draft of a letter from Zweig (without date). The letters refer to Romain Rolland, to Stendhal, and to articles by Zweig for Gorky's journal "Besseda".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. V of XIII

summary.ab: The file includes 45 handwritten letters, nine postcards and three telegrams. One of the postcards shows Rolland's house "Villa Olga" close to Genève. The letters deal with the international PEN club, with Rolland's travels to Austria and Germany, with Zweig's "Drei Meister" and with Mahatma Gandhi, Franz Masereel, Maxim Gorki, Paul Ollendorff, Albin Michel, and Emile Fabre.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 75 handwritten and typed letters, 35 postcards and three poems ("Durch blaues Glas", "Verse zum Gedächtnis für Hugo von Hofmannsthal", Blühende Mandelbäume"), arranged in two files. The letters were written in Palermo, Vienna, Taormina, Graz, Linz, Grundlsee, Florence, Arosa, Venice, and Finsterwaite. They refer to the works of both, to Braun's lecturer position in Palermo, to his travel to Tunisia, to the situation of German writers in exile, to his meetings with Hermann Hesse and Thomas Mann in Switzerland, to Zweig's support for others, to Braun's immigration to England, to Lavinia Mazzucchetti, to Arthur Schnitzler's funeral, to Alfons Petzold, Johan Bojer, Karl Reinhardt, Maria Malato, and Hans Leithelm.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The letter was previously stored in the Schwadron autographs collection.

summary.ab: The file contains one letter, written in Salzburg, referring to a meeting of both in Paris.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten postcard announcing a visit in Salzburg.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Copies of 41 handwritten letters, four postcards and two telegrams, written in Munich, Berlin, Sanary sur mer, Paris, Amsterdam, New York, Zandvoort, and Cannes. The letters refer to autographs, to publications and novels of both, to the Querido publishers in Amsterdam, to the literary journal "Die Sammlung", and to Erich Ebermayer, Erika Mann, Thomas Mann, Heinrich Mann, Joseph Roth, Annemarie Schwarzenbach, and Robert Klopstock.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter from the wife of the writer Carl Hauptmann, written in Berlin, reminding Zweig an earlier letter from her.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains five handwritten and typed letters, one postcard and two telegrams, which refer to plays, Tolstoi, and Moissi's planned tours to South America.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. VI of XIII

summary.ab: The file contains 42 handwritten letters, 14 postcards and one telegram. One postcard was written together with Marcel Martinet, another card shows the Villa Olga in Villeneuve together with Rolland and a woman. The letters refer to Frederic von Eeden, Erwin Rieger, Beethoven, Guido Adler, Rahel Varnhagen, Eduard Fuchs, Gandhi, and Tolstoi. In addition, some letters mention the Liber amicorum, the death of Zweig's father, the Mozartgemeinde, the Schopenhauergesellschaft, and the works of Rolland and Zweig.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of three handwritten postcards, referring to her ill son and asking for support with the Insel publishers.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 200 handwritten and typed letters, six postcards, and seven telegrams, written in Gliss, Cologne, Lwow, Warsaw, Frankfurt, Marseille, Paris, Berlin, Rapperswil, Ascona, Amsterdam, Brussels, and Oostende. Some of the handwritten letters exist in later typed transcripts, also two transcripts of letters from Roth to Lotte Altmann. In addition, the file includes the photocopy of one photograph showing Roth in Austrian uniform, and the typed novella "Die Büste des Kaisers" (34 pages). The photocopies are arranged in two files: 1927-1934, 1935-1938. The letters refer to publications of Zweig and Roth, to travels to Russia, to the mental illness of Roth's wife, to Roth's financial situation, to his attitude towards Judaism and the monarchy, to meetings of both, to Klaus Mann and his journal "Die Sammlung", to the publishers Kiepenheuer, Zsolnay, Insel, Querido and Humanitas, and to Robert Neumann, Hermann Kesten, and Thomas Mann.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Typescript of Zweig's story, fragment (missing p. 4 and the end), twelve pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten postcard, written in Dresden, apparently referring to Schurig's translation of Stendhal's "Rouge et le Noir".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 18 handwritten and typed letters, written in Paris, Rabat, Salzburg, and Fontainebleau, referring to publications and translations of their works, and to meetings of both.

titleStmt.title: Fragment eines Vorworts für die russische Ausgabe zweier Aufsätze von Zweig.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The letters were previously stored in the Schwadron autographs collection.

summary.ab: The file contains a fragment of a foreword, written in Moscow, to a Russian edition of two essays by Zweig.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. XII of XIII

summary.ab: 78 envelopes of letters sent to Zweig

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. VII of XIII

summary.ab: The file contains 40 handwritten and typed letters, and 11 postcards. The letters refer to Balzagette, Beethoven, Sigmund Freud, Ernst Bloch, Max Friedlaender, Arnold Zweig, Henri Gilbeaux, Hermann Hesse, and Henri Barbusse, as well as to the novel "Fouché" by Zweig, the visit of Gandhi at Rolland's home, the USSR and Rollands support of it (typescript of a supporting text against the Japanese aggression in the far east in 1932).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 29 handwritten and typed letters, 19 postcards and 3 telegrams, one letter from Mathilde Asch. The letters were written in Bad Gastein, Bellevue, New York, Vienna, Nice, London, and Baden b. Wien, and refer to meetings of both, to publications, among them to the translation of Zweigs "Der vergrabene Leuchter" into Yiddish, to lectures by Asch for supporting Polish Jews, and to Asch's impressions from his travel to Palestine.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti I.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 15 handwritten and typed letters, two postcards, and one letter by Mondadori publishers to Zweig. The letters refer to translations of Zweig's books into Italian, in particular his "Fouché", to repeated meetings between Zweig and Gorki and to the autobiography of Gandhi.

titleStmt.title: Wilhelm von Bode: Zum 400jährigem Todestag Peter Vischers des Aelteren.
Das Sebaldusgrab und seine Bedeutung
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Handwritten draft of an essay on the sculptor Peter Vischer d. Ä., six pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains newspaper clippings and programs concerning Stefan Zweig, among them texts by Mazzuchetti, 30 pages.

titleStmt.title: Alfred Döblin: 'Mit dem Blick zur Latinität'.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains the handwritten manuscript of the essay 'Mit dem Blick zur Latinität', referring to French literature, 14 pages, end missing (app. two pages).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of four handwritten letters and two postcards, written in Sorrento and Zuoz, referring to the emigration Einstein from Italy.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Typed copy of text on natural philosophy, apparently written around 1800, with handwritten corrections, nine pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals in possession of the Alberman family, London. The photocopies have been prepared for Prof. Paul M. Lützeler, Bloomington, Indiana, in 1974.

summary.ab: Phtocopies of 35 handwritten and typed letters, five postcards and two political essays ("Vorschlag zur Gruendung eines Forschungsinstitutes fuer politische Psychologie und zum Studium von Massenerscheinungen", "Zur Diktatur der Humanitaet innerhalb einer totalen Demokratie"). The letters were written in Vienna, Gössl, Munich, Alt Aussee, Clinton, Ct., and Princeton, and refer to meetings of both, to the performance of Broch's plays at theaters, to the translations of his works, to the publications of both, and to Broch's resolution addressed to the League of Nations. The file contains also photocopies of the correspondence between Richard Friedenthal and Paul M. Lützeler on the letters (1973-1974).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten and one typed letter, both written in Berlin, referring to Mozart and to Zweig's 50th birthday.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 36 typed and handwritten letters to and from Zweig, one postcard, and 3 notes, Most of the letters refer to Zweig's donations to the National Library, both of archival materials and of books.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopy of one handwritten letter, written in Boulogné/Seine, referring to publications.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of three typed letters, written in Berlin and Sanary, referring to Zweig's books.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti II.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 7 typed letters, referring to the translation of "Heilung des Geistes" into Italian and to financial matters.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti III.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 22 handwritten and typed letters, including two handwritten copies of letters, and two postcards. The letters refer to Zweig's lecture in Milan ("Die Geschichte des europäischen Gedankens"), to his work on "Marie Antoinette" and to the text for Strauss' opera "Die schweigsame Frau", to Max Reinhardt.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of one handwritten letter and two postcards, written in Berlin and London, referring to Stefan Zweig, travels to London, and offers to his wife to perform in theaters in South Africa.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Vol. VIII of XIII

summary.ab: The file includes 40 handwritten letters. They refer to the power of the Nazis in Germany and to possible actions against the European fascism, to Zweig's plans to leave Salzburg and Austria and possible alternatives, to Thomas Mann and his role, to "Die Sammlung", "Erasmus", "Maria Stuart", to the Schopenhauergesellschaft, the USSR and to Beethoven.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti IV.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 13 handwritten and typed letters, and six postcards, which refer to the political situation in Germany, to the resignation of Heinrich Mann from the Prussian Academy of Arts, to the attitude of Richard Strauss, to the translation of "Marie Antoinette" into Italian,to the sold movie rights of the same book in the USA, to his stay in London and his work on the book "Erasmus".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Several proof-sheets with handwritten corrections by Zweig, pp. 33-80, 65-80, altogether 64 pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopy of one handwritten letter, written in Temesvar.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 75 handwritten and typed letters, 35 postcards and three poems ("Durch blaues Glas", "Verse zum Gedächtnis für Hugo von Hofmannsthal", Blühende Mandelbäume"), arranged in two files. The letters were written in Palermo, Vienna, Taormina, Graz, Linz, Grundlsee, Florence, Arosa, Venice, and Finsterwaite. They refer to the works of both, to Braun's lecturer position in Palermo, to his travel to Tunisia, to the situation of German writers in exile, to his meetings with Hermann Hesse and Thomas Mann in Switzerland, to Zweig's support for others, to Braun's immigration to England, to Lavinia Mazzucchetti, to Arthur Schnitzler's funeral, to Alfons Petzold, Johan Bojer, Karl Reinhardt, Maria Malato, and Hans Leithelm.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of two handwritten letters, written in Nice, on a meeting and thanking for a book.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti V.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file includes 18 handwritten and typed letters, and six postcards. One of the letters is a copy of a French letter to Rusca. They refer to Zweig's thoughts about the death of Jakob Wassermann, to his intentions to publish his book on Erasmus and to translate it into Italian, to leaving his home in Salzburg, to the financial support of the poet Arthur Silbergleit, to a financial gift to Mazzucchetti, to Dora Mitzky, Alexander Moissi, Richard Strauss, and Heinrich Mann.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Typescript of Zweig's story with handwritten corrections, 34 pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains seven black&white photographies, four showing Stefan Zweig, two Lavinia Mazzucchetti, one his house in Salzburg, and one showing Friderike Zweig together with Hans Zohn.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of 200 handwritten and typed letters, six postcards, and seven telegrams, written in Gliss, Cologne, Lwow, Warsaw, Frankfurt, Marseille, Paris, Berlin, Rapperswil, Ascona, Amsterdam, Brussels, and Oostende. Some of the handwritten letters exist in later typed transcripts, also two transcripts of letters from Roth to Lotte Altmann. In addition, the file includes the photocopy of one photograph showing Roth in Austrian uniform, and the typed novella "Die Büste des Kaisers" (34 pages). The photocopies are arranged in two files: 1927-1934, 1935-1938. The letters refer to publications of Zweig and Roth, to travels to Russia, to the mental illness of Roth's wife, to Roth's financial situation, to his attitude towards Judaism and the monarchy, to meetings of both, to Klaus Mann and his journal "Die Sammlung", to the publishers Kiepenheuer, Zsolnay, Insel, Querido and Humanitas, and to Robert Neumann, Hermann Kesten, and Thomas Mann.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti VI.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 16 handwritten and typed letters, and two postcards. One fragmented letter apparently to Waldemar Jollos. The letters refer to Zweig's travel to the USA, to meetings with Toscanini, to Paul Stefan, Dora Mitzky, Alexander Moissi, Thomas Mann, Bruno Walter, to the Italian translation of the "Sternstunden der Menschheit" and to the first performance of the opera "Die schweigsame Frau".

titleStmt.title: Verlagsprospekt: Stefan Zweig im Herbert Reichner Verlag.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file includes a printed prospectus of books by Zweig published by Herbert Reichner publishing house (Vienna, Leipzig, Zürich), ten pages.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: Handwritten letter to the autograph's trader Hinterberger, expressing doubts about the authenticity of the Trenck manuscript, four pages.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti VII.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 13 handwritten and typed letters and five postcards, including three letters and two postcards to Waldemar Jollos. One letter was written by Lotte Altmann. The letters deal with Lenin, Dora Mitzky, Zweig's travel to South America, and his work on "Der begrabene Leuchter" and on "Magellan".

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: Originals held by the Reed Library, Fredonia College, NJ (USA).

summary.ab: Photocopies of two handwritten letters, written in Tel Aviv, referring to his thoughts to immigrate and to his exhibition in Palestine.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti VIII.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 16 handwritten and typed letters, and five postcards. Two of the letters were written by Lotte Altmann, one postcard by Zweig and Mazzucchetti was sent to Friderike Zweig. The letters refer to Zweig's travel to Italy, to Arturo Toscanini's 70th birthday, to the disposal of the house in Salzburg, to Waldemar Jollos' plays in Vienna, to the financial support of Erwin Rieger, to the work and translation of "Magellan" and to the travel of Mazzucchetti to England.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains a drawing made in occasion of Kubin's 60th birthday with a personal dedication to Zweig.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti IX.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 14 handwritten and typed letters, and 13 postcards. Three letters were written by Lotte Altmann, three postcards sent to Waldemar Jollos. The letters refer to Zweig's travel to Portugal, to the situation in Austria after the German occupation, to changes in the Italian translation of "Magellan", to the death of his mother, to the work on "Ungeduld des Herzens", and to Franz Werfel and Dora Mitzky.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig und Lotte Altmann an Edith Hoffmann.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The letters were previously stored in the Schwadron autographs collection.

summary.ab: The file contains one handwritten postcard by L. Altmann, written aboard a ship to Marseille, and one typed letter by Zweig to E. Hoffmann, written in London and referring to private matters.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The letters were previously stored in the Schwadron autographs collection.

summary.ab: The file contains two typed letters, written in London, referring to a meeting and to a Hebrew version of an interview (with Zweig?).

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti X.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains seven handwritten and typed letters and transcripts, some of them to Jollos, and three postcards. Two postcards and one letter were written to Waldemar Jollos. The letters refer to his travel in the USA, to his efforts to find a position for Mazzucchetti there, to Mazzucchetti's and his marriage, to his intentions to by a house in Bath, to his thoughts about the breakout of World War II, as well as to Thomas Mann and Arturo Toscanini.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains the typescript of a lecture given in Buenos Aires, with handwritten cancellations, 23 pages.

titleStmt.title: Stefan Zweig an Lavinia Mazzucchetti XI.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file includes three handwritten and typed letters and two postcards. One letter and the postcards were sent to Waldemar Jollos. They refer to Zweig's work on "Balzac", to Thomas Mann, and to his thoughts about writing an autobiography.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file (in two parts) contains the typescript with many handwritten corrections (by Lotte Zweig). It is labeled as fourth copy and once belonged to Alfredo Cahn, Zweig's translator into Spanish. Fifteen chapters, 501 pages. The first file contains chapters 1-7.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file (in two parts) contains the typescript with many handwritten corrections (by Lotte Zweig). It is labeled as fourth copy and once belonged to Alfredo Cahn, Zweig's translator into Spanish. Fifteen chapters, 501 pages. The second file contains chapters 8-15.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

notesStmt.note: The letters were previously stored in the Schwadron autographs collection.

summary.ab: The file contains the original suicide letter of Zweig, modern transcripts and a modern translation into Hebrew.

titleStmt.title: Hanna und Manfred Altmann, Richard Friedenthal: Briefe an Lavinia Mazzucchetti.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 13 letters and copies of letters by H. and M. Altmann and R. Friedenthal to L. Mazzucchetti and W. Jollos, concerning the publications of Stefan Zweig's works in Italian.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: בתיק: גליון של העיתון "העובד הציוני", מס' י"ד (4 במאי 1942) ובו תרגום עברי של פרק הסיום של הספר "ארסמוס מרוטרדם", מתרגם לא ידוע.

titleStmt.title: Gisella Selden-Goth, Erich Fitzbauer, Hanns Arens, Harry Zohn, Fischer-Verlag, Peter Vajo: Briefe an Lavinia Mazzucchetti.
TEST

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains letters and postcards concerning Stefan Zweig, the international Zweig society and publications about the author and for Friderike Zweig: Gisella Selden-Goth: one letter and two postcards (1945-1960) Erich Fitzbauer (Stefa-Zweig-Gesellschaft): three letters (1958-1959) Hanns Arens: one letter (1949) Harry Zohn: one letter (1952) Fischer-Verlag: one letter (1960) Peter Vajo: one letter (1962)

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains 15 handwritten and typed letters and one postcard, referring to Stefan Zweig, to the Italian translation of Friderike's biography on him, to the edition of the correspondence between Stefan and Friderike, to the "Bildbiographie" and to Thomas Mann and Reinhold Schneider.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One volume including a collection of newspaper clippings and photographs on Stefan Zweig, his suicide and funeral, collected by Leopoldo Berger, 83 pages. The volume was transferred to the library by Berger in 1960.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: The file contains mainly newspaper clippings about Zweig's life and works, one movie program on "Schachnovelle", 1960, "Blätter der international Stefan-Zweig-Gesellschaft", no. 1-15 (1958-1963), and "Archiv der internationalen Stefan-Zweig-Gesellschaft", no. 1-2 (1966-1968), as well as theater programs.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter to an unknown addressee.

publicationStmt.ab: Archive material in the National Library of Israel

summary.ab: One handwritten letter referring to literature, written in Vienna, two pages.
